title: Electrical Issues
description: Diagnose electrical problems on the Kymco Like 125i including lighting, charging, and wiring faults.

nodes.text: What electrical issue are you experiencing on your Like 125i?

options.text: Battery keeps dying or won't hold charge

nodes.instructions: For a non-working light on the Like 125i: (1) Check the bulb — remove and inspect the filament, (2) Check the fuse for that circuit in the fuse box near the battery. Replace any blown bulb or fuse with the correct rating. The Like 125i may use LED lighting on newer models — LEDs do not have filaments but can still fail.

nodes.text: Did replacing the bulb or fuse fix it?

nodes.warning: Disconnect the battery before probing connectors to prevent short circuits.
nodes.instructions: If bulb and fuse are good: (1) Check the related switch (dimmer, turn signal) for proper function, (2) Use a multimeter to check for 12V at the bulb socket with the switch on. No voltage means a wiring or switch fault. Check connectors along the wire path for corrosion or loose pins. The retro styling of the Like 125i means some wiring runs are longer than on other scooters.

options.text: No voltage at socket — wiring issue
Voltage present but no light — ground problem

nodes.warning: Keep hands away from moving parts while the engine is running.
nodes.instructions: With the Like 125i engine running at 3,000-4,000 RPM, measure voltage across the battery terminals. A working charging system should read 13.5V-14.8V. Below 13.0V means no charging. Above 15.0V means overcharging. If not charging, the stator or regulator/rectifier has failed.

nodes.warning: The stator produces AC voltage. Do not touch wires while the engine runs.
nodes.instructions: Disconnect the stator connector. Set multimeter to AC volts. With engine at 3,000 RPM, measure across the stator output wires. You should see 30-60V AC. If 0V or very low, the stator has failed. If proper AC voltage is present, the regulator/rectifier is faulty.

options.text: Low or no AC voltage — stator failed

nodes.instructions: Intermittent issues are almost always connection-related. Check: (1) Battery terminals, (2) Main harness connectors under the seat, (3) Handlebar switch connectors, (4) Ground wires at engine and frame. Clean corroded pins with contact cleaner, apply dielectric grease, and reconnect firmly.

nodes.warning: A completely dead system may indicate a major short. Proceed carefully.
nodes.instructions: If the Like 125i has no power at all: (1) Check battery terminal tightness, (2) Check main fuse near the battery, (3) Measure battery voltage. If the battery has voltage and fuse is good but nothing works, the ignition switch or main wiring ground may have failed.

options.text: Battery and fuse OK but no power

nodes.action: The light is working with the new bulb or fuse.
nodes.details: Keep spare bulbs and fuses. If bulbs blow frequently, check the regulator/rectifier output (should not exceed 14.8V).

nodes.warning: A short circuit can cause wiring fires. Do not keep replacing fuses. Professional diagnosis recommended.
nodes.action: Find and repair the short circuit in the affected circuit.
nodes.details: Disconnect loads one at a time to isolate which component causes the fuse to blow. Inspect wiring for bare wire touching ground. Common locations: headlight bracket, under seat, where harness runs along the frame.

nodes.action: Replace the faulty handlebar switch assembly.
nodes.details: Water ingress and corrosion cause switch failure. Replace with an OEM assembly. Apply dielectric grease to prevent future corrosion.

nodes.warning: Use soldered connections with heat-shrink tubing for permanent repairs.
nodes.action: Find and repair the damaged wiring.
nodes.details: Trace wiring from fuse to switch to bulb. Look for cut, chafed, or corroded wires where they pass through grommets or where body panels can pinch them.

nodes.action: Clean and secure the ground wire for the affected light.
nodes.details: Clean the ground contact point to bare metal, reconnect, and apply dielectric grease.

nodes.action: Check for a parasitic draw killing the battery when parked.
nodes.details: With ignition off, measure current between the negative cable and terminal. Normal is under 30mA. Remove fuses one at a time to identify the draining circuit. Common culprits: aftermarket accessories, alarm, faulty reg/rec.

nodes.warning: An overcharging system damages the battery and electronics. Replace promptly.
nodes.details: The reg/rec is mounted on the frame for heat dissipation. Clean the mounting surface for good heat transfer. After replacement, verify 13.5-14.8V at the battery with the engine running.

nodes.warning: Requires removing the flywheel with a puller tool.
nodes.details: The stator is inside the magneto cover. Requires a flywheel puller to access. This is an intermediate repair.

nodes.action: Corroded connectors have been cleaned and the problem is resolved.
nodes.details: Apply dielectric grease to prevent future corrosion. Check connectors every 6 months.

nodes.warning: Harness faults can be time-consuming to find. Consider professional help.
nodes.action: Inspect the wiring harness for chafed or broken wires.
nodes.details: Wiggle sections of the harness while monitoring the affected circuit. Common damage points: steering column flex point, under body panels, near battery area.

nodes.action: Battery terminals cleaned and reconnected securely.
nodes.details: Clean with wire brush, reconnect (negative last), apply dielectric grease.

nodes.warning: If it blows again, do not keep replacing. There is a major short.
nodes.action: Replace the main fuse with the correct rating.
nodes.details: Use exact same amperage. If it blows again, disconnect circuits systematically to find the short.
Replace with the correct type (typically YTX7A-BS). Check the charging system after installation to ensure it works properly.

nodes.warning: A faulty ignition switch can overheat. Replace promptly.
nodes.action: Test and replace the ignition switch if faulty.
nodes.details: Check for 12V on the output side of the ignition switch when turned to ON. If no voltage passes through, the switch contacts have failed. Replacement switches include the lock cylinder.
